blurb.content: I'm an undergraduate student at the
pursuing a B.Sc. (Double Honours) in Computer Science and Philosophy.
My free time is usually spent

readingList.title: Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
readingList.author: Douglas Adams
readingList.desc: I'm currently working through The Restaurant at the End of the Universe, but the series has already earned a spot on this list.

readingList.title: Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance
readingList.author: Robert Pirsig
readingList.desc: The narrator teaches some Zen philosophy while struggling with schizophrenia; it can definitely be a bit daunting with no background in Zen philosophy, but some motorcycle analogies can go a long way.

readingList.title: Mismatch
readingList.author: Kat Holmes
readingList.desc: Kat Holmes explains the concept of inclusive design and various ways it has been systemically forgotten or ignored; it's unbelievable to see its impact in failures in fighter jets and systematic racism through the heights of bridges.

readingList.author: George Orwell
readingList.desc: A classic, always worth a re-read every so often.

readingList.title: Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
readingList.author: Philip K. Dick
readingList.desc: I'm a big fan of cyberpunk, and the book is actually fairly different from the 1982 classic with Harrison Ford.

readingList.title: Brave New World
readingList.author: Aldous Huxley
readingList.desc: It's like Orwell, but upbeat and vaguely psychedelic.

readingList.title: At The Existentialist Cafe: Freedom, Being, and Apricot Cocktails
readingList.author: Sarah Bakewell
readingList.desc: A timeline of the surgence of existentialism and phenomenology, from Husserl to Sartre.

readingList.title: Dawn of the New Everything
readingList.author: Jaron Lanier
readingList.desc: One of the pioneers of Virtual Reality, the book alternates between a biography of Lanier's (bizarre) life, and fairly detailed breakdowns of ideas and developments in VR.

readingList.title: A Song of Ice and Fire
readingList.author: George RR Martin
readingList.desc: Definitively, the best fantasy/sci-fi series. At least we still have the books.

readingList.title: Island
readingList.author: Aldous Huxley
readingList.desc: Utopian opposite of Brave New World, Island follows a journalist, shipwrecked on an island, and his experiences with its inhabitants.
